comments:
This course is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. It analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.

Students found the course to be very interesting and useful. Many students like that the course “incorporates a lot of extremely relevant current events, especially in the current economy.” However, some students expressed concerns that “the text book does not match up well with the course” and that “there are too many number-crunching assignments.”

While many students called Professor Kahn “a nice guy” and a “genius,” most also wrote that he has “trouble communicating to students.” Students complained that it is difficult to pay attention because the instructor “needs to have more energy.” Students also find that the “power point slides are not great and should be organized more clearly.”

Most students in this course were Wharton sophomores completing the core. One student wrote that “group assignments were not helpful.” Many students also found the exams very difficult and believed that they were unprepared for the material tested as they “have several arbitrary questions.”

This course is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. It analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.

Students found the course to be very interesting and useful. Many students like that the course “incorporates a lot of extremely relevant current events, especially in the current economy.” However, some students expressed concerns that “the text book does not match up well with the course” and that “there are too many number-crunching assignments.”

While many students called Professor Kahn “a nice guy” and a “genius,” most also wrote that he has “trouble communicating to students.” Students complained that it is difficult to pay attention because the instructor “needs to have more energy.” Students also find that the “power point slides are not great and should be organized more clearly.”

Most students in this course were Wharton sophomores completing the core. One student wrote that “group assignments were not helpful.” Many students also found the exams very difficult and believed that they were unprepared for the material tested as they “have several arbitrary questions.”

This course is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. It analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.

Students wrote that the course was useful “for learning basic macroeconomics.” They also enjoyed the current event articles which the professor posted and the discussions about current affairs. One wrote that case students were useful, although “the number crunching was a bit repetitive.”

Most students expressed difficulty understanding the professor “due to his very thick French accent.” They also wrote that he “seemed to rush through some of the material” and that it was difficult to follow. However, students appreciated that “the professor was extremely accessible and willing to discuss course concepts.”

There were concerns that homework assignments were sometimes due right before exams and that “it was hard to manage the work especially since it was in groups.” Another student found the questions on the exam ambiguous. Others found the exams “extremely unfair and subjective.”

FNCE101 is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. The goal is to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy, which govern the global economic environment of business. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.

As an introductory finance course, this class focuses primarily on the economics side of finance rather than on technical material. Though recognizing the necessity of the course, many students felt like the course was lacking in finance content. Additionally, students believed the professor could have provided more real world applications of the material to supplement the theory-based lectures.

Professor Kurmann was described by his students and “warm,” “approachable,” and “humorous.” His presentation ability, preparedness, and enthusiasm were complimented, yet students did note his weakness in addressing student questions and concerns. Some would have preferred less use of PowerPoint presentations and more real world applications and commentary. Many felt that his teaching ability would improve.

FNCE 101 fulfills a core Business Fundamentals requirement for Wharton students. This class was found to be “challenging” by students who spent significant time on problem sets and often stayed up late at night on multiple occasions to meet a deadline. Many thought the traditional PowerPoint lectures became repetitive and boring, resulting in poor attendance as the semester progressed. This class was taught at 9:00 AM, which may also have deterred students. Some felt that the material from exams, class, and problem sets did not seem to coordinate well. This class was an Honors section. Though the class is curved, significantly more A’s are given.
